0MSmfn1lX0yYDAjVAl9mlA.text: Fried Hokkien Mee is my favourite local dish and I've been on a quest to find the best Fried Hokkien Mee in SG for a very long time. The best I had so far (I would give that 5 Yelp stars) was at a coffee shop beside the Aljunied MRT Station more than 20 years ago. I used to visit that stall quite often for a couple of years and really enjoyed the old uncle's fried Hokkien Mee. It was cooked perfectly - just the way I love it. Thereafter, I stopped visiting the coffee shop for a while, and to my dismay, when I visited it again, I found out that the Fried Hokkien Mee uncle has stopped operating at the coffee shop. I tried asking around where he has moved to, but no one seemed to know.So, for the past 20 years, I've been trying many many Fried Hokkien Mee Stalls in SG hoping to find something that is similar to my favourite Fried Hokkien Mee. Sad to say, my pursuit of my favourite dish proved to be futile as I was disappointed again and again, after trying many Fried Hokkien Mee Stalls. Fortunately for me, about 5 years ago, my foodie friends told me about the famous Geylang Lor 29 Fried Hokkien Mee. I went to try it straightaway and liked it a lot. Although, it's still quite different from my all-time favourite, I was happy I found one that I really like.You can imagine how happy I was when my friends told me that the Geylang Lor 29 stall has opened a branch in my hood. So, I can now get my fix for Fried Hokkien Mee whenever I needed it. What's even better is that it's even more convenient now as they do delivery via UberEATS. Just ordered one a few days ago via UberEATS and the food arrived in less than 20 minutes - fresh off the oven and piping hot. If you know of any good Fried Hokkien Mee stalls in SG, do let me know. I'll still like to try more until I find my perfect Fried Hokkien Mee. The search is not over. (Disclaimer: I don't work for UberEATS)

photos.caption: Photo of Geylang Lorong 29 Hokkien Mee - Singapore, Singapore. Ordered the medium size packet via UberEATS a few days ago. Enough to feed two.

z39GH9DEOTcg0nrxuHB5gg.text: Excellent hokkien mee. Wish there were more prawns than spring. But overall it had that unique charcoal taste and little bits of pork lard.

LaUI_ehOQhEW76D6hYHgnA.text: Long line for hokkien mee, but it is well worth it! Prices are fair, and portions are decent.I love how the noodles are "wet" and full of "wok hei". Definitely hits the spot.

PS_3j3rYL_irWpF0I_eTJA.text: Went there with high expectations ... but after $8 of HM(Hokkien Mee) for 1 person am only partially fulfilled . Have tasted much better @ 40% of the price . Over rated I feel and slightly bordering profiteering. Taste wise was not bad and tasted like HM (Hokkien Mee) . Have been eating this dish for 30++ years and know mediocrity when I see it . Portion wise felt like $3.50-$4 (...yes can be found still with just as good a taste)Will go back only when passing and having a HM Pang .

Ar4UqSiucjNIOr79h0vukQ.text: Every time we head to Singapore we find ourselves at Lorong 29 Fried Hokkien Mee at least once, if not twice during our short stay. It's always been consistent and has that awesome Wok Hei flavour or breath of the wok which is an indication of the level of skill of the chef in being able to achieve one of the foundations of a good wok cooked meal.The noodles are always cooked just right and the seafood by way of the juicy prawns and tender squid is also prepared perfectly. Hokkien Mee isn't the only dish they do there either and the Oluak or oyster omelette is beautiful too.If you're ever in Singapore, this is a must see or taste spot on your adventure the food paradise that is Singapore.

photos.caption: Photo of Geylang Lorong 29 Hokkien Mee - Singapore, Singapore. Food Court Shopfront..
Photo of Geylang Lorong 29 Hokkien Mee - Singapore, Singapore. Oluak and Hokkien Mee..
Photo of Geylang Lorong 29 Hokkien Mee - Singapore, Singapore. Hokkien Mee..

oNU890kRUgch4XFd809wLA.text: My three favourite words: cheap and good.This place has pedigree - it's been talked about for ages, it's moved away to Joo Chiat, and now come back, and there was talk about the uncle retiring, but the stall is still here, and the noodles are seriously YUM.Really flavourful stuff, fried just long enough to have some crispy edges (yes I like a little texture), and then there's the three prawns (in a "small"/$4 plate), the squid, and the pork lard. Ask for a little more sambal, and youI could sing its praises a little longer, but you'd spend your time better just going there now.Extra points for also offering carrot cake (okay this needs a mini-rave - again with the crispy edges, again with the prawns {who's got prawns in their carrot cakes nowsadays!?}), AND orh luah too (okay haven't tried this one).More extra points for being two doors down from Penny University - I can see a "morning coffee leading to lunchtime carrot cake" routine happening in my future.

photos.caption: Photo of Geylang Lorong 29 Hokkien Mee - Singapore, Singapore. Yes, they do carrot cake too

LKA2dYHrv0aj8T4FbJbHMQ.text: Maybe it's the high expectations I had for Singaporean noodles, but I thought the hokkien noodle dish was just alright. Cooked in quite a bit of oil and not as much of flavor. The place was clean...just like pretty much everywhere in Singapore.

ADSjmdo-DWj8nWklrN6mGQ.text: It has been quite a long time since I have really good hokkien mee, and I decided to search out one of the better known hokkien mee places in Singapore.It is not easy to cook good hokkien mee; there is always a certain x factor that differentiates average hokkien mee from the ones that are truly addictive. Well, suffice to say that the hokkien mee here is really up to mark. The gravy is very thick and flavorful, and the noodles (which consisted of yellow noodles and thick rice noodles) had just the right texture. The cook was also very generous with the portion of sotong and prawns!  Taste wise, this is among the best that I have eaten, and the freshness of the ingredients really brings up the quality of the hokkien mee here. This is definitely one of my highly recommended places for good hokkien mee!

photos.caption: Photo of Geylang Lorong 29 Hokkien Mee - Singapore, Singapore

2p0jQ8qnrL6j11-gUqOCcw.text: WHAT?!?!! Small for $6 now! That's a 50% increase! Big for $10! This is ridiculous! This will be my last visit! Good bye to another good place gone awry. :( ... and it's already passed CNY

kkOqq_wTFR24ZfqsFRm40A.text: This is one of the best Hokkien Mee left in Singapore (that i know of) fried the traditional way with a charcoal stove.The gravy is thick and maintains a rich prawn stock taste, while the yellow noodle is well fried with slight crispy bits and each noodle strand have been fried thoroughly to absorb the prawn stock.ingredients wise, the prawns are fresh and thick slices of sotong together with zhu you zhar and sambal chilli.

photos.caption: Photo of Geylang Lorong 29 Hokkien Mee - Singapore, Singapore

1xCILlwVaxyHckpLLxBX_w.text: A decent plate of hokkien mee is hard to find nowadays with all the masters either retired or left with disciples that cannot do it well. The Hokkien mee over here is well fried with a strong prawn stock that soaks into the noodles and comes with a tasty thick gravy. The noodles don't have the yellow chemical taste unlike most others for some reason and that makes it all the more better. The only way to eat Hokkien mee is with lots of sambal and the sambal here not only tastes great, but comes with great kick to it as well. Seating is rather spacious and not as cramped as you would expect it to be and there are smoking seats available as well, though they're rather near to the dumpsters. Parking is horrendous to be honest, with just 6 lots in a tight area. It's better and safer to just park at the lots located at Telok Kurau instead, a short 1 min walk away.

photos.caption: Photo of Geylang Lorong 29 Hokkien Mee - Singapore, Singapore

mE5CYtb9Fd31U8V-PdYkmA.text: Good traditional hokkien mee with generous amounts of prawns and squid. For some reason, I left hungrier than I arrived, the noodles makes you wanting for more!

photos.caption: Photo of Geylang Lorong 29 Hokkien Mee - Singapore, Singapore

bbivjIHEBZdM-H3D9DSbcQ.text: This version of Hokkien Mee is for fans who like more noodles than bee hoon. While you can definitely taste the seafood, it will be on the mushier side as the proportion of bee hoon is less.I prefer my Hokkien Mee with more bee hoon. Thus, this place doesn't hit the spot for me. I'll eat it regardless but it doesn't make me crave it.Call ahead to order before coming. The wait on weekends can be pretty long.

fmF_r7-xCH89eaxif9dEdA.text: Some come close, but this is to me the best fried hokkien mee in Singapore.Words do it no justice, and it's impossible to not finish your entire plate.A must-try for any hawker food lover.
